Salary is not to be proud of
Unnecessary paper work

headline: Excellent company to work for and learn latest technologies

Project dependent
Depending on promotion, raise varies

headline: Great Place
pros:
Great people 
Great cultue
Great compensation
cons: as a sales rep you want to see the company to be more sales orientated.

headline: Amazing Company ! great peer group, intelligent engineers .. If you love open source, this is the place to be !
pros: Red Hat is working on some of the coolest stuff going on in open source like openStack. N if you are an OS guy RHEL is always the place to be.  Very visionary senior management. I had the opportunity to listen to some of jim whitehurst talks, and I was convinced that he will take this company to places. very flexible work environment, overall a good place to be.
cons:
Not based on my personal experience, but from what I have heard, they are not a very good pay master.
Red hat has a lot of workforce who works remotely, Now it does give a lot of flexibility to people who are looking for that kind of option, it sometime takes away the fun of working in person. This can sometimes make your life at red hat a bit secluded. Mentorship is hard to find in remote working model. Like all big companies it will boil down to which team you are working for, and who is your manager.

RHEL is by far red hat most renowned product, and they are still not at par in other verticals, when it comes to their competitors. They are still trying to make a niche in their other business areas.

headline: Freedom, Flexibility and Meritocracy
pros: The great thing about Red Hat is that you in general are given the freedom to do what you want to do.  While demand is high, if you have a passion in a certain area, management is open to you taking your role in that direction.  Also depending on the role, there is a lot of flexibility to work from home/flex hours.  If you like working for a company that allows associates to be vocal and passionate, this is the place for you!
cons: With this kind of culture, often people are left to figure things out without too much guidance.  Some thrive in this environment, while others sink.  Also pay is not nearly competitive enough.

headline: Great company, great technology
pros: Working for a great company that focuses on new technology not just the stock market. You learn something new every day and the company backs you all teh way. Working here as a developer is a great experience.
cons: Not all postions are as well paid as the industry standard.

headline: Negative
pros: Great reach to latest in IT
cons: In U.K. They use people as thermometers and make sure there are enough borderline characters within the Organization

headline: Corporate management
pros: Dynamic, ever-changing, not boring, unique business model, great people
cons: Manager quality varies greatly across departments

headline: Great potential. Good pay
pros: Great potential to work in intersting products and tools

headline: Would be hard to leave
pros: The culture is very open and flexible. For the most part, employees can work from anywhere. There is definitely a "technology" company culture.
cons: It's a growing company and that has lead to communication channels being unclear or non-existent. While it's easy to get in touch with management, communication of ongoing activities seems to get lost.

headline: Good place to work if you like opensource
pros: Comfy environment with slow pace. Can learn a lot if willing to. No strict working hours. A lot of smart people you can learn from.
cons: The slow pace can make you lazy and you can actually start rotting there. Need to stay sharp and don't let the lack of discipline to lower your standards.

headline: Proud to be part of Red hat
pros: Flexible work hours. Work from home option. They value people. They don't sit on your head, rather let you take the accountability on your own.
cons: Annual pay rise is not yearly and irregular.

headline: Good, but growing fast
pros: Good work environment for starting out

Good Projects to work on and always exciting.
Great place to start your career and the company has a very good reputation when trying to move.

headline: Dedicated people
pros: Nice atmosphere with people who want to do well in their job.
cons: Not all departments have strong leaders who take the time to develop their team/department to not only perform a task/goal but to help them get to the next level in their career.

headline: It's an interesting and entertaining journey
pros: - Atmosphere, culture and people
cons: - If you don't have a clear direction of what you want to do, you may have trouble.

headline: Best to work with

pros: Red Hat Czech in Brno is great place to learn about new technologies. Engineers have great opportunities to grow and apply their knowledge. You can easily be part of great well-known project and become a guru.
cons: Not competitive compensation on Brno site. With skills required to work at Red Hat, it is easy to find employment in Brno that pays two times more.

headline: Red Hat has a dynamic and on-going environment.
pros: Red Hat is a good learning ground.
cons: There is need for work life balance in Red Hat.

headline: Awesome company for developers
pros: Work on opensource software with a lot of highly motivated, very savy people. Good salary.

headline: Engineer
pros: It was nice place to work. People are very frendly. The atomosphere was great.
cons: management is not good. Except for the management, people who work there was so nice. the salary range was a bit too low.

headline: It's easier to survive than succeed here
pros:
Smartest bunch of people I know under one roof. By far. 
Flexible, independent (depending on group) work.
Freedom to propose, have opinions and instill change.
Interesting, exciting and challenging environment. We may be many things, but not bored.
Innovative, take-risk, release often - fail fast environment.
cons:
Meritocracy is not as strong as the old-boys-network.
Building an org based the smartest, best in class, type A people requires management skills not present at all levels (promotions often seem based on technical, not managerial skills).
Instituting change can be slow and painful - ruling by consensus is not always efficient or effective.
Limited work experience outside Red Hat, many associates know only the Red Hat way. Not effective in trying to increase maturity in a large organization.

headline: Interesting
pros: Great Technology and training. great resources
cons: No loyalty or job security

headline: Enterprise or Startup
pros: Red Hat has some great people particularly on the technical side. They have develop some great solutions and technologies that have change the market place certainly with Linux Red Hat and Jboss. Great place to be if you are developer. Lots of good interesting projects to get involved with. New ways of thinking and a real chance to develop your skill set to your own benefit.
cons:
Red Hat are making that transition from startup to enterprise, certain people cannot make that change and are holding the company back.  Expect to be micro managed, expect a culture of blame down from some managers to their team and individual contributors. 
The company wastes a lot of time on reporting who is doing what, so much so that they are wasting huge amount of resources doing so. 
There is a strong sense of dis-jointment between the sales and the rest of the organisation. 
As a smaller enterprise there is a lot of favouritism that goes within the organisation. If you are not one of the favourites do not expect much chance of career progression and be prepare used to further the career of others.

headline: A rare company that practices what it preaches
pros:
Red Hat has a strong commitment to open-source software. It contributes to the advancement of technology around the world, allowing people to build atop the work of others to produce products and solutions greater than the sum of their parts.

The corporate culture is by far the finest I have experienced. The culture of collaboration permeates every level of the business.
cons:
Red Hat's salaries do not always measure up to the giants of Silicon Valley. The work-life balance can sometimes be difficult to maintain, as everyone in engineering performs multiple jobs.

Red Hat can be stingy at times, such as requiring employees to room together on business trips.

headline: Outstanding products and brilliant coworkers
pros: Truly lives up to the term "collaboration" and breathes the open source principles in day-to-day operations.  Some truly brilliant coworkers who are passionate about what they do.  The learning curve is very steep, but the environment is supportive and tech support engineers gain experience very quickly.  Train every TSE for RHCE and require they attain it to maintain their position.  Continue to develop internal and external tools to streamline workflow and make the organization more efficient.
cons: The compensation is far from competitive.  This aids in attracting those who are passionate about the technology and open source culture; however, it is difficult to raise a family and pay debts on the poor pay.  Also causes a constant churn of the most skilled engineers.

headline: Growing company, great potential for career advancement.
pros: With the right management structure, lots of ability to change roles to fit current interests and needs.
cons: Corporate structure has grown and core OSS values have been de-emphasized.

headline: Do not work for Red Hat IT.
pros: The company as a hole, has great people and some great goals. If you work in Engineering, fantastic place to work. People who believe in what they are doing and love it. When I first began working there, I really enjoyed it, but things really went down hill.
cons: The IT department is full of incompetent people and people who are there due to nepotism. I really feel sad at having to say this, but the current CIO has really dragged the place down. They implemented ITIL and have generally preferred closed source solutions over ones that Red Hat itself sells. Just completely insane that they would put in place closed source solutions that specifically compete with Red Hat products.

headline: Red Hat Review
pros: Great company.   Employees are passionate about the company's mission and objectives.
cons: Smaller company (6,000) employees, so there is not an unlimited number of resources as compared to an Oracle or Microsoft.

headline: Extremely fast growing, dynamic and fun company
pros: one can be part of building up a company, every day new challenges
cons: too US centric marketing organization

headline: Far and away the best job I've ever had
pros: My job is challenging to the point of not knowing whether I can succeed, which provides quite a thrill once you get used to it. Also, I get to work on truly ground-breaking ideas that I've never even thought about before joining the company. Finally, people listen to you here...no matter whether you've just joined and they're a few levels up the management chain, if your ideas are good they get attention.
cons: The business is growing so fast it can be pretty hard to keep up with the things you need to know to do your job. Also, because we're so interested in technological innovation, it seems like we're constantly interested in a slightly better solution than the one we have (for a given internal need). These collude to produce an environment where documentation can sometimes be hard to find, and it can mean tracking down a specific person to get answers you need to do your work. Since we're a truly global business, that may mean dealing with awkward timezone differences to ask questions.

headline: Great technical team, a lot of bright and fun people here
pros:
A lot of people work from home
Great colleagues
High visibility in the open source community
Good chance to work on high profile projects
cons: Small teams scattered over several timezones and often not enough resources to get the work done in the way one would wish

headline: Great
pros: technology, products, growth, people, opportunities
cons: some old minded sales directors

headline: I get to do what I love to do
pros: I work remote. They care more about results than hours worked. I get to work with the open source community. The managers have a high respect for their engineers. Everyone I work with is a team player, there's no dead weight. It's hard to write 20 words about the"cons" of working here ;-)
cons: They really want you to share hotel rooms when you travel. You have to give weekly status reports. You have to take ethics training once a year (via online).

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Exposure to open source ,latest technology and development communities and conferences
Good work life balance
Good compensation and benefits
Challenging and high learning curve
cons:
Senior management has lot of scope for improvement
Restricts promotions for foreigners
Minimal Onsite Opportunities

headline: Great company - plan to stick around for a long time
pros: A great company to work for. I've been there for many years, and it still has a small-ish feel even though it has grown 5x (employees) during that time. Most of my coworkers in the engineering department are smart, motivated, and good to work with. They stick to their principles of open source. Communication internally is very good. I feel like in general, the company cares about their employees and tries (within reason) to make us happy. It's a stable environment and I've never felt any concerns about layoffs or downsizing - if anything it's the opposite (growing pains).
cons: Of all the jobs I've had internally, I've found management to be very hands-off. i.e. "You know what you need to do, so do it". At times I've wished I had more direction, but I'd take that over a micromanager.

headline: Great Culture. Passionate People.
pros: The culture, people, and work environment has kept me here. I'm amazed everyday by the passion and commitment of folks I work with. It makes it a great place to work.
cons: Rapid pace of change won't be for everyone. If you don't like change, then Red Hat probably isn't a good fit for you.

headline: Awesome Company!! Get paid to be part of the solutions not the problem.
pros: Every open-minded and creative culture. Truly values their employees. After all opensource is about community. Redhat even as a gowning company keep the core values of source strong.
cons: Very tech savy company. Those that like to use MS word and Outlook for mail may find it quite different.

headline: A fulfilling experience, working with highly motivated people who are full of energy and who are not afraid to speak up.
pros: Open environment, good perks and benefits, great location in downtown Raleigh.
cons: Lots of meetings where things are not always accomplished.

headline: Great people, great company
pros:
1. Employees are very passionate about open source, transparency, meritocracy, collaboration, etc.  
2. Employees understand and articulate the company values and hold each other accountable to them.  
3. Everyone is willing to pitch in to help solve a problem.  This sometimes results in 'too many cooks in the kitchen', but the eagerness to help creates a very supportive environment.
4.  Smart people who know their jobs.  Technical expertise in most functions is very high.
cons:
As others have mentioned, pay is not up to industry standard.  Red Hat has had extraordinary growth, and it becomes increasingly hard to justify lack of raises and low salaries to the employees, given the profitability of the company.

Career mobility is limited in certain departments and is very manager-dependent.  A bad manager can kill a subordinate's career.  Hasn't happened to me (fortunately), but I've seen this a lot.  

Speaking of which, we have some good managers, but we have a lot of BAD people managers.  The skills that it takes to be a good engineer, software developer, lawyer, accountant, etc are a very different from the soft skills needed to manage people.  Our HR is too focused on managers filling out forms as opposed to giving them real training on how to appropriately manage people.

headline: Lots of positive energy and momentum and a very flexible work culture
pros:
- Lots of energy and positive momentum 
- What an individual/team wants to do is unbounded by the company in many ways. One can decide for themselves how hard they want to work or choose a more balanced work life balance (but still work and not goof off)
- the core competency of the company is open source technology knowledge and the free exchange of it on email lists and discussions. Provides a very valuable learning opportunity
- Company has great relationship with customers (large enterprises) - something that can be very useful for getting ur job done effectively.
cons:
- Lack of any significant processes. So sometimes it feels like re-inventing the wheel. 
- Compensation is average

headline: Unlimited opportunity to enrich career continually preparing you for the next step.
pros: Values, Focus on strategy and execution, unlimited opportunity from a career perspective, work-life balance.
cons: Growing pains from a startup to billion+ dollar business.

headline: Principal Software Engineer
pros: Best place to work on open source software.  Help create the software that the world runs their businesses on.  Flexibility to work from many locations around the world.  Anyone can contribute to our open source projects and the very best developers (e.g. best patches submitted) can be considered for our open positions.
cons: We are a large company, which can be a con.  Although, we still have a small company feel in that we have many different initiatives that employees can be part of.

headline: If you want to do technical work - Look no farther.I worked as Technical Support Engineer and the learning is incredible
pros:
1) Numero uno company to work on linux. And by linux, I mean enterprise grade, performance choking linux. Not fancy fanboy stuff (though it's still there). Put it simply, you put effort. You will reap astonishing benefit of the technology.

2) Incredible technology stack and unparalleled learning curve. You will meet and work with folks you never would have anticipated.

3) Outstanding people from all over the globe. And most of those guys (not the petty, mediocre sacks) are hell-bent to help you - provided you put the genuine effort. Result - A far better, improved technologist and probably better skilled, paid engineer.

4) It's open source baby (it's still now - subjected to change with the way of growth).

5) Add all four.
cons:
1) In India, the management is all squeaky and engaged in skirmish. The micromanagement has been induced to a great painstaking level and it irritates the good guys at work. People who are technically less adept will listen to those bs talks but guys who know their knowledge, will not care. Therefore, you will see good attrition rate of good employees. Don't trust me, ask the existing employees.

2) Bad, bad hiring. Right now, they are only inclined to hire technically inferior people/folks with no aspiration. That is demotivating.

3) Not everyone likes to work in weekend, night shift, holidays. It should be made _crystal-clear_ to everyone at the point of hiring that 'hey, this is support. All the unholy sum up will be there, as long as you are here'.

4) Once you are technically good and have achieved STSE/TSE/TAM level, it is *hard* to progress much. Because, with given workload, you won't be able to pursue own studies, unless you spend sleepless nights alone with a computer. And the management folks won't let you pursue higher. 

5) IMPORTANT - please let an engineer be another engineer's manager. I have had lots of managers and I don't think one of them was better than me, either technically or academically. For a company of the standard of Red Hat, that is pathetic. In fact, I know that most of them weren't engineers at all. Some mere team leads here and there with some management jargon which they blurb on the new guys.

headline: RH FTW!
pros: The sky is the limit! No, really, it is. You can probably do anything you want to do here. Managers have been extremely supportive in crafting a career path as well as making sure they  I find the work fulfilling
cons: The pay is weak. I know a lot of people say this about their jobs, especially since the great recession. And especially since IT pay has been getting lower and cheaper the past handful of years. But Red Hat does definitely pay less for the non-management / non-rockstar positions. :(

headline: Senior consultant
pros: Many Challenging engagements. Innovating products.
cons: too much travel and not enough time to maintain expertise

headline: sr. software engineer (middleware)
pros:
- hight flexibility (working remotely)
- passioned and smart people
- low bureaucracy (reporting is reduced to a bare minimum)
- open source done right
cons:
- salaries are not where they should be. Most of the salary increases are triggered by engineers and not by management 
- working remotely has its challenges (self discipline)

headline: Great company, great co-workers
pros: People are excited about the work they're doing. Lots of freedom to do the right thing. Open source mentality cuts out a lot (but not all) of the bureaucratic nonsense. The office and work environment are nice, modern and a lot of fun.
cons: Lots of systems to work with, and not all of them are well-integrated, leading to patchwork business processes, questions about ownership, and some duplicated effort between teams.

headline: Great opportunity for those who look for it!
pros: Excellent work atmosphere, great cafeteria and game room to relax in when needed.  Downtown location is great for entertaining clients and potential customers.  Management on most teams are very supportive and excited to have intelligent, energetic people working for them.
cons:
Getting qualified people hired via referrals is tough (Recruiters -)
Growing pains mostly, lack of great communication between departments.

headline: Excellent work environment !
pros: Great career opportunities and values. Training & development-focused
cons: In process of becoming a large corporation

headline: Looks better from the outside
pros:
Good compensation.
Benefits are good.
They invest in training people which is better than the industry norm.
cons:
Poor sales management. 
Lack of vision to grow company.
It's a political albatross, make sure you kiss ass to management or there will be repercussions.
RH looks for followers, not leaders.  Sales management is the classic, 'Emperor wearing no clothes'....best to collect your (very well compensated) paycheck than try to make positive changes.
Long term future is very dim once the maintenance renewals start slowing down.

headline: Lots of opportunity to work on open source, poorly run internal projects and products.
pros: Red Hat is committed to open source development and if you want to work in that environment and not have a company hassle you about participating in the open source community, Red Hat is good.
cons: Very weak regional office representation.  Weak brand identity in the software industry.  Confusion among customers about what Red Hat does (Linux?  JBoss?  Something with Cloud?).  Little to no recognition for significant project contributions.  Low pay for the industry and very low raises.  No guidance for career path and impossible internal mobility.

headline: Red Hat Software Engineer
pros: Talented people, interesting work, opinion is valued, unique open source experience
cons: Flat hierarchy + Outside hiring creates lack of growth opportunity

headline: Nice place to work five
pros: Good place to learn five
cons: Support is high pressure five

headline: A company that really understands how to use technology in the modern workplace
pros:
There is no salary cap that forces a jump from engineering to management. 
Management makes effective use of communications (email, chat, phone, video-conference) to ensure that remotees are plugged into whats going on.
Most development groups allow remote employees
Upper management seems to be managing for the long haul as opposed to targeting the next earning call. 
Even though we're pushing 6000 employees, we haven't quite lost the feel of a startup. It's not quite as loose and crazy as it was in 2000 but it's not shirt-and-tie corporate America either.
No "that's not your job" culture. People tend to jump in an fix something rather than trying to push it off on someone else.
cons: Still see a reluctance to hire US engineers, probably due to salary/benefits issues. That being said, if someone is well-known in their field, space can be made.

headline: The company is in continuous growth and there's plenty of opportunity to grow with it.
pros: The pervasive Open Source mindset throughout all levels distinguishes Red Hat from any other company. Everyone is happy -- even eager -- to help and accomplishments are lauded widely.
cons: There's still some restructuring left to do.

headline: Best place I have ever worked
pros: Great team, Great company, Awesome job.
cons: Starting pay is not very competitive.

headline: Challenging and very fullfilling
pros: It is a definate meritocracy where your views and comments are considered and listened to. Every associate has the ability to change the company.
cons: Every one has a voice which means some people can become complete divas. The transition from small company to big one is a little painful but the management are dealing with this in a positve way.

headline: Red Hat is a great place to work
pros: Awesome culture, great people, just a great company to work for
cons: Compensation is not that of an Enterprise Software Company

headline: Smart people and fun work!
pros: Able to work remotely on flexible hours. Management does a good job of keeping the red tape off you plate and just wants you to succeed.
cons: If you are new to open source or just new to the company there are lot of things that should be listed in a beginners guide.  Like how we use git or maven central.  The knowledge is there it is just silo'ed. At least if you ask people are willing to share.

headline: excellent place to work and grow
pros: freedom to do what you think is best
cons: lack of structure can hurt some people

headline: good place to work
pros:
* You can really learn a lot about linux here. And mastering Linux opens a lot of doors for future. 
* Most engineers here are very friendly, experienced and very resourceful. 
* Great life and work balance. Flexible working hours.
cons:
* Traditional development management style and release cycle (this could be good or bad depends on your own opinion)
* Not enough training opportunities here, includes RedHat's own RHCE class (not enough class offered)

headline: A senior engineer's view of Red Hat
pros: Flexible working hours, high pedigree engineering team, low management interference.  Lifestyle - working remotely, etc - and highly encouraged community participation.
cons: Below average pay scale, increasingly political environment.  Product management wrestling increasing control over upstream open source projects.  Somewhat adversarial relationship between business and engineering.

headline: Best company for graduate students.
pros:
Opensource values.
Lot of opportunities for graduate students.
Young collective.
Informal and very friendly atmosphere.
Great management which is in touch with lower employees.
Benefits are good.
cons:
Absolutely lack of employees on senior level = after few years there's nobody to learn from.
No real career development.
Salary under average.

headline: High performance culture
pros: Transparent work environment; very talented and hard working workforce; strong culture; employees care about company success; approachable leadership team; minimal politics
cons: Long work week; pay only average to slightly below average; all areas are not open to workplace flexibility

headline: depends on the department
pros: lots of sharp people to work with. fast paced environment where you learn on the fly.
cons: doesn't seem to pay competitively in some departments such as global support services. Some departments are still nice to work for and will pay and treat people appropriately. Global support services however has taken the lower road. little freedom to do the right thing is given and micromanagement is a real problem. you will not even get close to your market value and the low pay is not worth staying in this kind of environment.

headline: Director
pros: Great culture in an enterprise package, its like a big - small company. Lots of opportunity and a lot less politics. Fiscally prudent and stable.
cons: Typical pains of a rapidly growing company.

headline: Good for linux enthusiasts
pros: Freedom and choice to work from home policy.
cons: One needs to be self-driven in order to establish vertical growth in company. Else, one would notice doing same routine work again and again and no rise in salary.

headline: Awesome place to work if you are passionate about anything related
pros: Awesome place to work for
cons: Being open source, things are not as streamlined as proprietary companies. That's both a challenge and an opportunity

headline: Red Hat Services
pros: Diversity of work and exposure to open source products in many verticals. See how real customers struggle to integrate and implement what marketing and sales make seem "easy".
cons:
Consultant corporate culture more concerned with title, whining, and CYA. Probably one of the worse culture types where on the surface  "one team",  behind the scenes all risk management and blame gaming. In an environment where it's already difficult to deliver under optimal conditions you cannot trust your peers or managers here. No bueno.

Oh yes, and the solutions are often not very well thought out.

headline: Challenging work, great environment.
pros: Great culture, work environment, people, and open source ideals.
cons: I don't have any complaints.

headline: Flexible work, good work, good people.
pros:
RH has the right attitude about remote employees -- and it works very well for us.  Maybe you've heard anti-remote ideas lately from other companies.  They are living in the past.

RH is the corporate face of open source.  It's pretty easy for me to believe that what we're doing here actually matters.

The people I've met here ( in 5 years ) are smart, easy to get along with, and a pleasure to work with.   

I realize this sounds a little like I'm seriously drinking the KoolAid.  Well -- okay.  I've had a lot of jobs in the last 20 years, and this is the first place I've really liked.
cons: Being remote can get a little isolating -- a weird combination of always being in touch with everybody, and never seeing anybody.

headline: A cool place to work with.
pros:
A cool place to work with in terms of flexibility with restrictions on what you should do.
A place where you are limited by your own learning limits.
Access to the some of the best minds.
cons:
Would be great to have the flexibility to work remotely (India) or from a office closer to home.
A paygrade which is more focused on perks

headline: Cool place to work, gives freedom to employee
pros: open source, FOSS concepts followed
cons: Less pay compare to service based

headline: OK but not the dream that was sold to me
pros: Open Source Technology is cool
cons:
No transparency with management
While they claim to be approachable... they aren't. Not at all.
Very little diversity within organization (e.g. mostly Old White Males. The End.)
Working with an enterprise product stack is less interesting than you might think

headline: not that good
pros:
- open source world with access to all projects and open community to get help and advises
- good work environment, awesome devel engineers to work with
- growing fast as open source company
cons:
- low salary
- low transparency and many uncertain workflow
- no promising career path
- no exiting training opportunity and resource
- mission driven workloads without enough break for skills enhance and new tech training

headline: Great place to work
pros: good evironment and high skilled managers
cons: low paying, less transperancy, less benifits

headline: Good people, good technology, bad compensation.
pros: The open source culture is very nice as is the technology.  Most everyone I worked with was good.  Training was available both in classes and on the intranet.  Remote work opportunities were good, with plenty of support provided for remote employees.
cons: As an SE my commission was very poorly done, and completely unobtainable.   It seed like they promised X to make it look like a great position, but really only intended to pay out 75% of that.

headline: Red Hat
pros: Excellent company with a great unique culture.
cons: Can be a little siloed.

headline: Very good
pros: Red Hat has strong company values, and a unique business model that makes it well positioned for success.  It is a medium sized company with a big company presence
cons: Office locations are far from city centers.  I think this is a strategic move to keep real estate costs down, but I also believe it makes current employees unhappy and detracts against getting the "right kind" of new employees.

headline: Time to sell some salami
pros: Good salary, flexible work environment, some flexibility in job assignments, not too demanding with bench work. Management is responsive to your opinions and suggestions. Management generally asks if you are comfortable with assignments.
cons: Sometimes isolating fro remote employees. Management is not afraid to throw consultants into situations that are less than ideal. They can send you into an assignment alone where you have no experience with a product that they sold you on as an expert.

headline: Growth is change
pros: Fast growth provides new openings and positions and a lot of chances to move up fast. There is a lot of training and upper management truly supports you.
cons: Fast growth presents change and sometimes it's hard to keep up. Other then that I can see no downsides.

headline: Figuring out who they are.
pros: Great people, great technology, fun atmosphere
cons: Turning into one of the big boys is making RHT loose it's focus.

headline: Never a dull moment
pros:
Fast paced innovative company
Very collabarative approach
internal mobility is encouraged.
cons: Lack of structure is not for everyone

headline: Work environment is beyond toxic
pros: The company product and mission is solid (with the exception of the JBoss side of the company).
cons: The products from the JBoss group are terrible as are the people who work there. I witnessed people screaming obscenities at each other in meetings, flaming each other over email in front of management and peers, and just general playground bully behavior that would result in termination at any other company. Oddly, the CEO recently discussed this culture in an article as if it were a positive. I can assure you that being insulted and degraded on a daily basis isn't cute, or clever, or tolerable. I and most of the people I on-boarded with lasted no more than a year.

headline: Very tactical sales management,  company lacks vision and ability to expand revenue with other solutions
pros:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux WAS a game changer
Has the building blocks - middleware, virtualization, lifecycle....
cons: Quota's go up on average 75% to 100% a year, 73% of company revenue comes from the operating system because there is no sales training (or deep dive competitive information on the sales portal) on the middleware stack and other solutions which would enable sales people to cross sell effectively and overachieve quota.  Linux has become mature and this company needs to become more competitive with their other solutions.  Management is inept - incredibly so.  They are tactically focused on the weekly forecast call, lots of politics and there is an "old boys mentality" - if you're not one of the "boys" you have accounts taken away from you and the management simply doesn't support you when you need them.  BTW - this is an engineering company - I've been in a meeting where an senior solutions architect stated in front of a room of sales guys that the sales guys are "slime that oozes from under rocks".  I was with RH for quite a few years - these are not first impression observations

headline: Good company, but too bureaucratic

headline: Great Company for experienced employees

cons: Not a ton of position growth unless someone is fired or you move to an entirely new position. Because of the outspokeness...some comments can be harsh or offensive. Definitely need a thick skin.

headline: A company that proves that some innovation lies in the concept of creating value itself.
pros: Great culture, good benefits, freedom to innovate.

headline: Great and rewarding experience
pros:
- great colleagues

- freedom culture

headline: Great culture, bright future, very accomodating.

cons: None yet.  Travel may get old, but they offer to accomodate when it does.

headline: Great Place To Work!!
pros: Great team spirit, fun, creative and fast paced
cons: Some systems can frustrate at times....

headline: Excellent!
pros: Great place to work. Collaborative mindset. You are in the heart of a world class company that defines how IT business is done.
cons: Problematic tools, disjointed information, processes still in development.

headline: Great place
pros: Some of the smartest people I have ever worked with, and most of them are nice as well. I think virtually everyone at Red Hat that holds a technical job is there because they believe in the open source models.
cons:
Some managers are very out of touch.

headline: Learned a lot

headline: Great company that desperately needs an improvement on management skills
pros: Good culture and growing company. Energetic and fun quarterly meetings!!
cons: Several managers operate their department depending on their own personality traits.  There is a known lack of professionalism on how they should motivate and train their employees.  One manager consistently roams up and down the isles micro managing causing employee wagers on how often she will interrupt them daily.   Another one would repeat confidential conversations with her subordinates for merely office gossip, causing tension within the workplace on how to respond/react. Drama galore!

headline: Open source company ruled by sales drones
pros:
- technical challenges

cons:

As a consequence many of the very skilled people in europe who raise the company to the $1B have left demotivated and tired of it.

headline: Technical Support Meh

headline: Manager

International company

Well known in tech circles

competing silos of messaging and strategy 
hidden agendas of upper management

headline: Great place to work
pros: The open culture at Red Hat is a real thing and is infused in all aspects of the business. Of course that does not mean that "every" decision is made by committee. Red Hat still has a business to run so this of course makes sense. The work Red Hat is doing is relevant, industry changing and innovative. Employees are passionate and willing to challenge one another to produce their best work.

headline: I *love* working for Red Hat
pros: Everything I do supports making Open Source Software available to folks who might not otherwise have access to this kind of tech.

headline: Love working for Red Hat
pros: Culture, work life balance, pay, the people..........I could go on and on, I've been with Red Hat over 6yrs and can't think of ever leaving.  Product innovation is great, customer service is superior to any other and management does a great job not getting in our way.
cons: some turnover in Sr. Leadership has cause for concern.  New leadership at the top seems to not have the "open source" culture that is the back bone of this organization.  Giving it time, but could be cause for future concern that some want Red Hat to be like IBM and Oracle.

headline: Great company with good benefits and brilliant people
pros: Lots of projects all over the country

headline: Innovation and Accountability
pros: Great technology.  Leaders that mentor.

headline: Great employer!!

headline: Excellent opportunity to help customers with the world of open source enterprise software!

headline: Life At Red Hat
pros: Passionate people who really care about open source technology.  Able to progress with your own ideas if you build the right relationships with the right people.

headline: Growth opportunities, but lots of frustrating road blocks along the way

-free snacks/drinks/first aid kit

-pay seems low compared to past experience with similar tech companies
-because the company has grown rapidly, many processes dont exist. Even if processes are in place, they're often not followed in order to cater to the "tenured" employees
-bad mentality from tenured employees with attitude of "this is how its always been done, so why should we change"
-long hours are the norm
-upper management (depending on department) shows obvious favoritism to those who kiss a$$
-very little work/life balance. if you need to leave early to pick up your children or go to a doctor's appointment, you're almost frowned upon (at least in my experience)

headline: Fast paced environment, great people. Middle management needs help.
pros:

-Many have issues with middle management - across the board

headline: Challenging and Encouraging of Growth
pros: It's awesome to work with everyone around you engrossed in building a better software company. Management is pretty transparent, and decisions are made fairly quickly.

headline: Excellent company to work for!
pros: Great work environment, unique people, excellent benefits, free food, free drinks, etc...

headline: Red Hat ROCKS!
pros: A truly open and collaborative environment! Red Hat hires smart people, and senior management is very strategic and driven. Red Hat is a GREAT place to work!
cons: Sometimes because everyone gets to share their $0.02 is slows down a project, but at the end of the day you usually with a better, more informed decision at the end of the day.

headline: Very clickish unprofessional and disappointing environment
pros: It says a lot when the only Pro I can come up with is free snacks. The pay can be generous albeit short lived.
cons: Management is able to go rouge. No polices in place to protect employees from a bad manager. Take "Right to Work State" too literally with no respect for employee well being. People tend to "disapper" not a positive work environment.

headline: Two sides, one company
pros: Enormously bright people -- more than anything else, everyone is _proactive_ and professional. The work is challenging, you are rarely pigeon-holed (confined to only one type of work/role) and lots of room for growth and new ideas.
cons: Red Hat is really, really political, especially on the engineering side -- sometimes, it almost feels like an academic atmosphere in that respect, which is good on the idea side, but bad on the political side.

headline: Challenging and satisfying
pros:
- Working with cutting edge technologies and best of minds
- Great open-source culture
- Repeat, great open-source culture
- Opportunity for intra-company transfers
- Great learning opportunities
- Bonus and other perks...
cons: - Sometime, it is difficult to track employees from other departments :)

headline: A place full of bright and exciting people.
pros: Lots of people with sharp minds and interesting ideas. Associates are strongly encouraged to work in community, share information, discuss ideas and step up.
cons: All places have bad apples, if you know what I mean...

headline: Best Company I've Worked for
pros: Red Hat has a great culture. They value everyone's opinion no matter their title. People here have strong opinions and are respectful of others' opinions--in fact, they expect you to voice yours. After all, this is a open-source software company. Community and diverse opinions often lead to better products. In addition, the benefits, salaries, and bonuses are great. They may not be the highest in the world, but they're certainly trying to make each employee feel valued. My manager and his peers are often very encouraging of my work and welcoming of new, fresh ideas. In fact, they go out of their way to reward you. I've been in companies where hierarchy was more important, and salaries and bonuses were based on quantitative results (rather than qualitative). There are many huge company events, team events, extracurricular activities (sponsored soccer teams, etc.) and clubs to join. Free food & snacks. Upper Management/Execs are approachable and don't carry the elitist stigma. Once you're an employee, they continue to try and make sure you're happy and on a path to success. If this includes moving to another team, picking up new skills, or moving to another city (remote or not) then they'll make sure it happens.
cons: You get thrown in to the mix quickly and are expected to swim. If you're on the right team (which is most teams, but not all), you'll have several helping hands. The Brand team sticks to themselves and is often unaware (and doesn't care) that there are other experienced designers in the company. For non-designers, this may not be an issue. Every other team that I have worked with has been awesome and accommodating.

headline: Good company with a terrible IT department
pros: I believe the overall company is a good one and the environment seems to be positive outside of IT. I like the company's mission and how they seem to be executing on it.
cons: The IT department in the company seems to be exclusively concerned with covering the ass of upper management. Even the simplest technical problems are solved with the addition of more process on an already overly burdened system. While I was there, the IT department was rife with blatant nepotism and conflicts of interest. Even those that prove that they are toxic for the company are simply moved to other areas of IT and not terminated. Worse, the process has been shown to cause outages, yet the answer is to add more process. Between this blind pursuit of process and the toxic working environment, I am glad to be out of there and would never recommend anyone work in Red Hat IT.

headline: Fantastic working environment, great colleagues
pros: Great colleagues, great culture & freedom to explore
cons: The same formal cadence as any enterprise company

headline: A challenging environment with lots of smart people that allows you to bring out your best

* Challenges you to evaluate and improve your own ideas to solve problems
* With not much effort you can interact with people across the company
* Opportunities for career enhancing training
cons:
* Like a small company, often struggling to do a lot with few resources or people
* Like a big company, starting to experience some drag from processes that haven't kept up with growth

headline: The best company EVER!
pros: Interesting technology, autonomy, small company feel with big company perks, working with some of the best technical minds in software, the sky is the limit for career growth.
cons: Would be nice if travel was planned for more in advance. Seems like a lot of last minute decisions in that regard.

headline: Challenging and full of growth opportunities

It is clearly a company where innovation is driven by community.
It has grown a lot and since the products are open source, the real capital of the company is people
cons: Red Hat has grown very fast and not everything is well organized, which can be viewed by some as a drawback but also as with lots of available spaces for creative people.

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: A great environment for improvement. They value people who have a steep learning curve, and people that they see have potential. don't slack! It's still a pretty small company and your not just a cog in the wheel.
cons: Not really any cons. I love it here, the people are great and we have a lot of things in common. The cultural fit is important since you will be working a lot in teams.

headline: Smart, passionate people working together for a common goal.

People here are generally smart and passionate about what they do.
The company cares about its employees and tries to provide opportunities for advancement and education.
The company is always tackling interesting projects and hard problems, there is always a lot of challenging work that needs to be done if you know where to look.
Overall I consider it a very good place to work.
cons:
Interdepartmental cooperation is not what it should be.
It is unclear what (if any) value some middle managers are contributing.
The company does a bad job of firing unproductive individual contributors or managers; people tend to just linger indefinitely while continuing to be unproductive.

like minded people

real lack of understanding of the wold outside the USA.

headline: Fast paced, innovative & collaborative and employees have a good work/life balance in my view.
author_position: Branding Specialist [ I Just Left This Department of Unhappy Old Hags]
pros: Great technology, innovation, employees are encouraged to speak up. Red Hat has a dynamic global work force and hires the top talent no matter where they live in the world. Employees are not micro-managed and are empowered to utilize their skills and experience in their fields.

RedHat's corporate "branding" team thinks they run the company and members step out of their boundaries to monitor every social post or opinion of employees who blog, tweet or just have opinions they express on a social media platform. I'd bet someone in branding will read this review and attempt to stick their 2 to 4 cents in on my post.

 Management might be too focused on wall street and keeping analysts happy at times;

headline: Disaster in making
pros: Open source, still growing company, lots of opportunities, lots of offices, sex appeal in tech circles.
cons: Red Hat has grown too fast and is becoming too much of a big company. If you are about to be laid off from HP or AMD, you will find yourself at home at Red Hat -- which is trying to become like HP or AMD. Red Hat lost its spirit of a smaller counter-culture company, and it's trying to impose (top-down) processes for operational efficiency. The open source developers who are still employed are less and less connected to the corporate entity which is all about process formality.

headline: Political People - here's your place to shine

Nice new digs downtown
cons:
Political
Old guards or "connected" rule
Bad behavior seems to get many promoted
Very spin focused culture lacking substance
Open source behavior is not happening consistently
Underpays significantly and does not pay more as they quadruple your work - no regular evaluations based on continued expansion of responsibilities (this may also happen while you watch the person next to you do nothing)
Very difficult to attain work life balance - all depends on your manager - 90% are not supportive of this
Fast paced to the point of chaos 
Too much shifting priorities/roles; job can end at any moment where someone makes up a new one for you or you disappear

headline: All depends on your boss
pros:

cons:

headline: Very very busy
pros: Engineers are very bright and very dedicated.  Really fun to work with them.  Sales and Marketing are above average.  Administrative staff are fine.
cons: A lot of work.  Product lines are expanding and people are not being hired fast enough.  While Red Hat has become a big company but internal processes and procedures are more geared to a small company.  It is nice for a large company to try to be nimble and agile like a small company but it is not possible.

headline: Great open-source culture, smart people, approachable management.
pros:
1. Open-source culture promotes a lot of collaboration and transparency of other projects. There is always someone to listen to your ideas and discuss with you. If you want to be involved in something, just ask!

2. Working with smart people makes you smarter! Higher effective conversations, many great ideas flowing around. It really gets you thinking outside of the box.

3. Management including our executives are all very approachable and down to earth. If you have an issue, or just want to chat, they will almost always have time for you!
cons: Cons really depend on your individual team's dynamic and what group you are with. So it's hard to say.

headline: Great people and they care about their employees
pros:
- Incredible people
- Solid benefits
- Good pay if you negotiate properly
- Stock options
- Great CEO
- Fast paced
cons:
- Sometimes too fast paced
- Chaotic due to the true open source culture (lots of collaboration)
- No clear progression or career path, it can be difficult to figure out how you'll grow here (lots of folks do though)

headline: Quickly growing, passionate people, rewarding work
pros: The company is growing so quickly, there's a lot of opportunity to move around and grow along with it. You work with some of the most passionate open source advocates around and your work can directly impact the company's success.
cons: Quickly growing is a two-edged sword. It's fun to be a part of, but processes tend to lag the growth rate, which leads to occasional frustration.

headline: Great culture, good talent, growing pains
pros:
Collaborative environment
Mid-level management is involved and responsive
Real value is placed on software
Development staff is very talented
Transparency is a priority
Embraces technology market shifts
Contributes to the community
cons:
Compensation not competitive in some areas
Rapid growth is stretching management and infrastructure resources
Limited career growth in some departments

headline: Still a great company to work for.
pros: A company with solid financials, great people, freedom, and a strong culture.
cons: HR is not on the ball. Career opportunities exist but require too much politicking. Senior management is a mixed bag, some great, some old timers out of their league.

headline: Amazing company, tough challenges
pros:
Close-knit and cooperative

Growth perspectives within the organization are limited

headline: Corporate America
pros: Open Source.  Lots of good people.  Plenty of room for growth.  Lots of offices, so you can move where you like.  In tech circles, there is a certain amount of sex appeal.  I.e. for a large multinational IT corporate, Red Hat has a lot better rep than Microsoft.  Great servers, good pay, and lots of perks.
cons:
While we're technically "open source", we're not really.  The business model is, put out great software with crappy documentation, then sell services.  For my money, if I were starting a business, I'd go CentOS.  Mind you, Red Hat is a necessary evil.  CentOS wouldn't exist if someone didn't pay Red Hat to continually improve their product.

If you hear "open source" and think cutting edge and open, go somewhere else.  Red Hat is a major corporation and it's run like one.

headline: Fantastic place to work at!
pros: You get to work with the brightest people in the IT industry. Pay is not bad and your get to work with fantastic open source software.
cons: Internal process is not well defined.

headline: Good (but could be great) place to work.
pros: Red Hat's open source culture creates a climate where associates' opinions are heard and people are encouraged to participate in decision making. In general, the staff at Red Hat is extremely bright and competant.  Red Hat's management is supportive and respectful and they encourage an excellent work-life balance.
cons:
Red Hat's compensation and benefits package is not competitive with other high tech companies (at least in the Boston area, which is where I work). Associates are expected to "work for less"  to have the privlege of working for the open source leader. There are many open source advocates who are willing to work for less, but this attitude will deter many excellent potential staff members from considering Red Hat.

Red Hat is also experiencing some growing pains with respect to processes and tools. Processes are extremely complex,. As we grow, these processes and tools will not scale. More streamlined processes need to be instituted to allow Red Hat to grow successfully. Thereis too much red tape and management approvals to be flexible and efficient.

headline: Fantastic workplace, innovative people, exciting environment, freedom to act independently
pros: There are tons of pros here. Every day I learn something new; every week I have an experience that promotes both my personal professional career and the company as well. I feel like I'm making an impact in the industry, and that my contributions are visible at an individual level. My soul is not being sucked into a corporate machine.
cons: The only con that I have is the fact that I work from home and don't have access to any offices (there are none nearby,) but that can easily also be viewed as a pro for many. I just need more daily interaction to feel that I am doing my best.

headline: folks are out there to change the world
pros: Best team of open source hackers bar none; high density of very senior, very skilled developers available to consult at any given time.
cons: Lots of Type A personalities - need to know how to handle, manage, negotiate through constant tech conflicts and debates. Lots of changes in priorities constant change of the latest and greatest new thing makes it hard to keep on long term development without being interrupted.

headline: Passionate but still Immature company.

cons:
- Lack of seniority and strategic vision from part o Sales and specially from Marketing.
- Starting to show the growing pains of juvenile companies, such as: Bad, cost management (penny wise, pound foolish). Whole departments are being created to avoid firing people that don't perform.

headline: Open source, open company
pros:
The internal culture at Red Hat is incredibly open and diverse. It is not uncommon to see engineers and "workers" openly criticize management when they feel that a poor decision has been made.

Reliable financials and internal movement means you will never worry about losing your job.

Amazing coworkers and frequently amazing managers.
cons:
Lack of driving technical vision. 
Overly conservative investment strategy from senior management when it comes to diversifying the product portfolio or being creative in penetrating new markets or driving deeper into existing markets. (This falls into the "it aint broke, dont fix it" category of business management and Red Hat excels at it  - for better or worse)
